subject.topic: BP Deepwater Horizon Explosion and Oil Spill, 2010

mods.abstract: Oncale answers a series of questions about demographics of Bayou Lafourche. He discusses major industries of fishing and oil; he likes to fish recreationally but works in the oil fields as a contract welder. He discusses the impact of Deepwater Horizon oil spill on the local economy, and the growth of Port Fourchon as a center of industry. He discusses flooding and living above the floodgates. He describes his house in Golden Meadow, and his relationship with his neighbors. He describes increase in traffic with the new highway to Port Fourchon, and the impact and possible abatement of coastal erosion.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.2097. A digital version of the index (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Brigette Noble and Lauren Fonda.

Gary Oncale was born in Thibodaux, Louisiana, in 1953. He lived in Bogalusa, Louisiana, in the early 1980s and then moved to Golden Meadow in 1982 [1985?]. He is a contract welder in the Bayou Lafourche area, but travels extensively through Louisiana and Texas for his work. He is a volunteer firefighter in Golden Meadow. Oncale did not speak at length about his personal life, but he was raised Catholic and the interviewer made a note about his grandson.
